thinking.disposable_income: Greater Eastwood has a moderate median household income around $53,000, with about 20% of residents living below poverty level, indicating limited disposable income for many residents.
thinking.discretionary_consumption: The neighborhood has moderate discretionary spending capacity, with many working-class families needing to carefully budget transportation costs against other essential expenses.
thinking.accessibility: The area has good access to downtown via multiple bus routes and the East End light rail line, with about 20% of residents using public transit for commuting, while most households own at least one car.
thinking.decision_rationale: 1) Prioritized proposals with lower transit fares ($0.75) to benefit transit-dependent residents while maintaining service quality. 2) Favored moderate sales tax (1%) to support transit without overly burdening household budgets. 3) Supported moderate driving fees ($0.50) to encourage transit use and fund improvements while not excessively penalizing necessary car trips. 4) Considered travel time improvements for both transit and car users. 5) Balanced revenue generation for transit improvements against impact on household budgets.
